hints_html: The first two conditions specify the behaviour of the slope of the tangent lines of \(f(x)\) at points near \(x = 0\) and the last condition specifies a point that the function \(f(x)\) must pass through.
hints_latex:
The first two conditions specify the behaviour of the slope of the
tangent lines of $f(x)$ at points near $x = 0$ and the last condition
specifies a point that the function $f(x)$ must pass through.
hints_raw: The first two conditions specify the behaviour of the slope of the tangent lines of <math>f(x)</math> at points near <math>x = 0</math> and the last condition specifies a point that the function <math>f(x)</math> must pass through.
question: 1 (e)
sols_html: There are infinitely many possible solutions to this problem. As long you sketch a continuous function that has slope equal to 1 the near \(x = 0\) on the left, a slope equal to -1 near \(x = 0\) on the right and touches the point \((0,3)\), then you should get full marks. Click the images below to see a couple of examples.
sols_latex:
There are infinitely many possible solutions to this problem. As long
you sketch a continuous function that has slope equal to 1 the near
$x = 0$ on the left, a slope equal to -1 near $x = 0$ on the right and
touches the point $(0,3)$, then you should get full marks. Click the
images below to see a couple of examples.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH104/December_2012/MATH104FINAL_2012_1e_1.png}

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH104/December_2012/MATH104FINAL_2012_1e_2.png}
sols_raw:
There are infinitely many possible solutions to this problem. As long you sketch a <b>continuous</b> function that has slope equal to 1 the near <math>x = 0</math> on the left, a slope equal to -1 near <math>x = 0</math> on the right and touches the point <math>(0,3)</math>, then you should get full marks. Click the images below to see a couple of examples.

[[File:MATH104FINAL 2012 1e 1.png|left|thumbnail|400px|alt=Alt text|A possible solution]]

[[File:MATH104FINAL 2012 1e 2.png|left|thumbnail|400px|alt=Alt text|Another possible solution]]
statement_html:
Sketch the graph of a continuous function f(x) satisfying:

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x\to0^-}f'(x)=1,\qquad\lim_{x\to0^+}f'(x)=-1,\qquad{}f(0)=3\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Sketch the graph of a continuous function f(x) satisfying:

:<math>
\lim_{x\to0^-}f'(x)=1,\qquad\lim_{x\to0^+}f'(x)=-1,\qquad{}f(0)=3
</math>
